item.title: Statistical significance in big phase 3 studies
item.description:
I came across this article from a senior clinician calling for a change in the way we interpret statistical significance. Of course, this is not a new debate, but it caught my attention because:

  1. It’s referring specifically to very big phase 3 clinical studies.
  2. Everyone seemed to agree with it, whereas I don’t (fully).

It gives the example of the CHARM study where candesartan was compared to placebo in a randomized trial with 3023 patients. The primary endpoints was time-to-event, where the event was “cardiovascular death of admission to hospital for chronic heart failure”. The result was a hazard ratio of 0.86 with 95% confidence interval of (0.74, 1.00) and a p-value of 0.051.
